a: Psoriasis is caused by an increased production of skin cells and a problem with the immune system. It can also be triggered by certain events such as an injury to the skin or throat infections.

q: What are the treatment options for psoriasis?

q: Can psoriasis affect a person's quality of life?
a: Yes, psoriasis can have a significant impact on a person's quality of life, especially if the condition is severe. It can affect one's physical appearance, cause joint pain, and affect mental well-being. It is important to seek support and treatment if needed.

q: How common is psoriasis in the UK?
a: Psoriasis affects around 2 in 100 people in the UK. It can start at any age, but most often develops in adults between 20 and 30 years old and between 50 and 60 years old.

q: What are the common areas of the body where psoriasis patches appear?
